docs.snippet: 8 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES  The 120-seat Curry Lounge has recently undergone a million-dollar renovation, with décor right out of Bollywood. But the menu is do-it-yourself, which makes life more than difficult for the head c...
docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (BBC America) RAMSAY'S KITCHEN NIGHTMARES The 120-seat Curry Lounge has recently undergone a million-dollar renovation, with décor right out of Bollywood. But the menu is do-it-yourself, which makes life more than difficult for the head chef, who must concoct unfamiliar dishes for each order. Here Gordon Ramsay, above right with the chef Zahir, tries to fix his first Indian restaurant. 6:30 P.M. (Cinemax) THE ONE PERCENT Jamie Johnson, a great-grandson of the founder of Johnson & Johnson and the Emmy-nominated director of the documentary ''Born Rich,'' in which several young heirs did the unthinkable and talked about their family money, focuses this time on the growing gap between the rich and everyone else in America. Specifically, he examines the 1 percent of society that controls nearly half of the nation's wealth. Among those offering their opinions: the economist Milton Friedman; the billionaire Adnan Khashoggi; Roy O. Martin, a Louisiana lumber tycoon who spends with the Bible as his guide; Chuck Collins, a great-grandson of Oscar Mayer who gave up his inheritance for moral reasons; and Bill Gates Sr., the father of the richest man in the United States.

docs.abstract: The Bagger heads West, to the Big Show.

docs.snippet: The critic makes short work of those who call the Oscars a bi-coastal display of elitism....
docs.lead_paragraph: It's time for the perennial "whither Oscar?" stories, the ones in which writers feel obliged to bemoan either the lowest-common-denominator or the elitist tastes of the Academy. Andrew O'Hehir of Salon drops a grenade on the latter.
docs.abstract: The critic makes short work of those who call the Oscars a bi-coastal display of elitism.

docs.snippet: An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Chr...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Wednesday about the conduct of the United States attorney for New Jersey, Christopher J. Christie, referred incorrectly to the political relationship between Mr. Christie and John Inglesino, a partner at a law firm to which Mr. Christie — as a United States attorney — awarded a contract to monitor the University of Medicine and Dentistry of New Jersey. And a correction in this space on Saturday referred incorrectly to the awarding of that contract. Although Mr. Christie and Mr. Inglesino served on the Morris County freehold board, they never served together. (Mr. Christie served from 1995 to 1997 and Mr. Inglesino from 2001 to 2007.) And Mr. Christie’s former law firm was not involved in awarding the contract.

docs.snippet: An article on Friday about the Food and Drug Administration breaking its own rules by not inspecting a plant in China that made the active ingredient of a blood-thinning drug misspelled part of the name of the company that founded American Capital...
docs.lead_paragraph: An article on Friday about the Food and Drug Administration breaking its own rules by not inspecting a plant in China that made the active ingredient of a blood-thinning drug misspelled part of the name of the company that founded American Capital Strategies Ltd., the majority owner of Scientific Protein Laboratories, which owns the plant. It is Oscar Mayer, not Meyer.
